e4: I would not recommend changing to the new policy because the CFO believes that changing the policy without bias will be perceived by most investors as a negative earnings report, which could negatively affect stock price and give an unfair trade advantage to sophisticated investors. This potential market reaction outweighs any potential benefits of transparency.
e5: I would view an ethical reporting policy as one that is transparent, accurate, and respectful to all stakeholders. In this context, it means disclosing actual earnings figures without knowingly misleading investors through implied bias or omission. A robust ethics framework should also consider the potential consequences of disclosures on different types of stakeholders, such as retail vs institutional investors, and prioritize fairness in information dissemination.
e6: Yes. I would ask for more information on the potential consequences of not adjusting the earnings, such as increased legal liability or scrutiny from regulatory bodies, and how management plans to address these concerns in their decision-making process.
